bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 9, 1902

div1.p: Reed writes that he is returning to Cuba, and includes other political news about those who are candidates for Surgeon General. He says Roach's orchards are alive with locusts and expresses concern.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 9, 1902
div1.opener:
Don't forget about
Locusts on Trees.
Monday Evening-
My precious Miss “Windy”,
div1.p:
Whew! how
the wind did blow at your hospita-
ble ranch on yesterday! As a raiser
of ye howling zephrs, you are the
greatest success that I know of-
Well, as I “poneyed” along the road,
who should come along but Dr
& Mrs. Roach & the children- They
kindly picked me up & carried me
down to the Station -- on the way down
the mountain, I had a long chat
with Dr Atkinson -- Miss Pattie's doctor-
He seems to be a very pleasant gentleman --
and is very fond of the Hopkins peo-
ple- I ate my tongue sandwich in
Baltimore and got home at 9 o'clock.
I found a letter from Col. Scott,
Gen. Wood's Adjutant General, ex-
tending to me an invitation to be
present at a dinner to be given
to Gen. Wood in Boston, next-
Friday night by President Eliott
of Harvard & some others- Said
that the General was very anxious
that I should be present and that
the Secretary of War would be
present also- I wrote, at once, stating
how much I appreciated the Cour-
tesy, but that my duties on the Ex-
amining Board would prevent my
acceptance- Today, I dropped
in on the General, at the Everett,
to pay my respects, and was much
surprised when he told me that
he had already accepted an
invitation for me, and that the
Secretary of War was very desi-
rous that I should be present-
It seems that the dinner w is
to be given to Gen. Wood & those
members of his staff who were
engaged in civil work in Cuba,
& as the General says that what
I accomplished was of, the most
importance of all, I must be
there- Under the circumstances
I must go -- will get back in
time, I hope, to catch the afternoon
train for Blue Ridge and spend
Sunday amidst the howling tempest
again- I hope to obtain some def-
inite information about the per-
manent S. G. before I get back.
Forwood you know, has been
appointed- I went in to see him;
this afternoon & extended my
hearty congratulations- He seemed
to be very much gratified over his
appointment- Gen. Wood told me that
very strong pressure was being brought
to have Col. Smart promoted and
retired after Forwood's time expired.
I had your rocking chairs & Sewing-Ma-
chine taken down to the Museum, to-
day -- & am having it & the lounge cra-
ted by Mr Wild -- Will ship them
with other things on Wednesday --
ordered your star, this afternoon,
will ship whisky tomorrow-
Col. Carter has been made a Brig-
adier General in the line- Dr Roach
says locusts are dreadful in his or-
chard- Please tell Jacob to go over all
of my trees every morning & kill all on
them- Don't forget this- Love to the
girls -- 8 candidates before us --
Love & kisses for my precious babies-
